Entry.body:
<p><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">The Austrian Jewish author Stefan Zweig was undoubtedly one of the great intellectuals of the 20<sup>th</sup> century. His novels, novellas, and historical biographies were best sellers, and were translated into more than fifty languages. <span style=" color: black; background: white;">He was extremely popular in Europe as well as in the United States and South America, and remains so today in Continental Europe. As a pacifist and a humanist who conceived the idea of a united Europe, an idea which was completely surreal at the time, Zweig was ahead of his time. </span></span></p>
<p> </p>

<p class="MsoListParagraph" style=" margin-left: 54.0pt; line-height: 150%;"><span style=" font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;"><span style=" font-size: medium;">Zweig was born in </span></span><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna"><span style=" font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;"><span style=" font-size: medium;">Vienna</span></span></a><span style=" font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;"><span style=" font-size: medium;"> to a wealthy </span></span><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish"><span style=" font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;"><span style=" font-size: medium;">Jewish</span></span></a><span><span style=" font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;"><span style=" font-size: medium;"> </span><span style=" color: black;"><span style=" font-size: medium;">family. His father was a </span></span></span></span><span style=" font-family: Calibri,sans-serif; color: black;"><span style=" font-size: medium;">textile manufacturer, and his mother came from a Jewish banking family. </span></span><span style=" font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;"><span style=" font-size: medium;">Already in his teens Zweig sent poems and articles to literary journals and corresponded with important literary figures. He also started a collection of manuscripts which included manuscripts of Goethe and Beethoven. Later on this collection came to include a catalogue of Mozart's works written in Mozart's own hand!</span></span></p>

<p class="MsoListParagraphCxSpLast" style=" margin-left: 54.0pt; line-height: 150%;"><span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 150%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black;">In the following decade Zweig moved constantly between Vienna, Berlin, Paris and Brussels. During this period he made the acquaintance of  famous poets, writers and artists such as Auguste Rodin, Rainer Maria Rilke, Romain Rolland, W.B. Yeats, Pirandello and many others. It was during this period that he started to write novellas and dramas which were warmly accepted by audiences.</span></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">In his student years Zweig wrote poetry as well as short texts and stories. Some of these were published in the leading newspaper of Vienna, the <i>Neue Freie Presse</i>. The literary editor of this paper was none other than Theodor Herzl, the leading figure in the National Jewish movement. Herzl became a mentor of the young Zweig, for whom publication in this prestigious newspaper was conceived as a literary knighthood, especially for a beginning writer.</p>

<p class="defaultstyle"><span style="font-family: "Gentium Plus"; font-size: 13.5pt;">After the war Elimelech Basch's brother Jacob, who survived the Holocaust, came back and found the diary. He later gave it to Basch's only remaining daughter - Perhiya -  who lives in Israel. She, in turn, decided to donate the diary for safekeeping to the National library of Israel for the generations to come.</span></p>

<p class="MsoListParagraph" style=" line-height: 150%;"><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 150%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black;">When WWI broke out, Zweig, a patriotic Austrian, at first wrote pro-war articles. When the war began Zweig was conscripted and assigned to serve in the Austrian Archives of the Ministry of War. Having been exposed to the horrors of the war, Zweig underwent a significant change, and wrote a fervent anti-war drama called Jeremiah which won the acclaim of his friend, the famous author Thomas Mann. It was at that time, that Zweig  adopted an extreme pacifist position, as did his friend  the French </span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 150%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">novelist </span><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romain_Rolland" title="Romain Rolland"><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 150%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">Romain Rolland</span></a><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 150%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">. He then moved to </span><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland"><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 150%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">Switzerland</span></a><span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 150%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;"> </span></span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 150%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">until the end of the war. Zweig remained a pacifist all his life and advocated the unification of Europe.</span></p>

<p align="left" class="DefaultStyle" style="text-align: left; margin-left: 32.2pt;"><span style="background: white;">Following this composition, Maimonides wrote his most famous treatise called the <i>Mishneh Torah</i>, a comprehensive code of Jewish Law which is conceived throughout the Jewish world as <span style="color: black;">one of the chief authoritative codifications of Jewish law and ethics, as well as other important writings. In this great composition Maimonides broke from</span></span> one thousand years of legal precedent of writing commentaries to produce a systematic codification of Jewish law by subject. Although most of Maimonides’ treatises were written in Judeo-Arabic, Maimonides composed the Code in Hebrew<span style="color: red;"> </span>to ensure its accessibility for Jews all over the world.The manuscript was copied in Spain between 1300-1350, and illustrated around 1400 in Perugia, by the artist Matteo Di Ser Cambio.</p>
<p align="left" class="DefaultStyle" style="text-align: left; margin-left: 32.2pt;" dir="LTR"> </p>
<p>The NLI houses a large collection of Torah manuscripts. We present to you here some of the finest of them, Scrolls as well as Codices.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">In a gradual process which began in the last quarter of the 19<sup>th</sup> century, and  continued until the rise of the Nazis, Jews in the German-speaking world had made a transition from exclusion to acceptance. While until then Jews who wanted to take part in these societies usually had to convert to Christianity, a definite change took place after 1848, when many former restrictions were lifted. Jews were especially successful in the employment of these opportunities for advancement through education. It is this trend which allowed Kafka Zweig, and Benjamin to study at the university, and made the idea of Benjamin receiving a university position tenable.  Jews had become intellectual leaders in the German-speaking world. </p>

<p style=" margin: 0cm; margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 13.6pt;"><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: #313131;">Walter Benjamin is widely known as a literary critic, translator, essayist, philosopher, intellectual and the great urban wanderer of the twentieth century. For many, Benjamin’s life and death, writings and philosophy, epitomize the twentieth century and the many changes it heralded, from the rise of popular culture, the advent of photography and the emergence of the urban realm as the primary arena of human experience, to the tension between myth and reality, eternity and apocalypse.</span></p>

<p style=" margin-top: 4.8pt; margin-right: 0cm; margin-bottom: 6.0pt; margin-left: 54.0pt; line-height: 14.4pt; background: white;"><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black;">In 1920 Zweig married Friderike Maria von Winternitz (whom he divorced in 1938), and moved into a grand house in Salzburg. In the following years he wrote a series of novellas and biographical works, which were full of emotional tensions and situations of social and psychological crises on issues such as gambling, prostitution, adultery, and suicide.Zweig's works became extremely popular, and were criticized by some of his colleagues as "railway carriage reading". Among these novellas were <i>Amok, Fear, Compulsion</i> and </span><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twenty-Four_Hours_in_the_Life_of_a_Woman" title="Twenty-Four Hours in the Life of a Woman"><i><span style=" font-size: 9.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; background: white;">Twenty-Four Hours in the Life of a Woman</span></i></a><span style=" font-size: 9.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; background: white;">,</span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black;"> while the biographical works included Marie-Antoinette, Joseph Fouché and Magellan.</span></p>

<p class="MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst" style=" margin-left: 35.45pt;"><span style=" font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;">Zweig's autobiography, </span><i><span style=" font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;">The World of Yesterday</span></i><span style=" font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;">, preserves not only the memories of Zweig's life, but the memories of the cultural era, from the end of the 19<sup>th</sup> century to the onset of WWII. Zweig describes his days as a young boy, his experiences as a student, and the support he received from Theodore Herzl as a young and promising writer. Zweig does not only glorify this era, but expressly points out its drawbacks.</span></p>
<p class="MsoListParagraphCxSpLast" style=" margin-left: 35.45pt;"><span style=" font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;">The typescript in the NLI is the only existing copy which is intact and contains corrections which were made by his wife Lotte. The copy was donated to the NLI by the translator of Zweig to Spanish, Alfredo Cahn, who lives in Argentina.</span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style=" text-autospace: none;"><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">This lesson is a basic exposition of the <i>Ari</i>'s teaching regarding the process of creation.  According to this lesson/discourse God <span style=" color: black; background: white;">began the process of creation by "contracting" (<i>Tzimtzum</i>) his </span>infinite <span style=" color: black; background: white;">light in order to allow for a vacuum in which </span><span style=" background: white;">finite<span><span style=" color: black;"> </span></span><span style=" color: black;">and seemingly independent realms could exist. </span></span>At this point time began and the root of “strict justice” (<i>din</i>) was secreted into this vacuum, mixed with the remnants of Divine Light still remaining in it. The goal of humanity is to salvage these spiritual lights and so bring to the restoration (<i>tikkun</i>) of the spiritual lights which have fallen under the domination of the forces of evil called “shells” (</span><i><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">kelippot).</span></i></p>

<p><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">At his request, his enormous book collection (some 25,000 titles) was transferred to the National Library upon his death in 1982, and  the Gershom Scholem Collection for Kabbalah Research was instituted. This special reading room, which today contains approximately 35,000 titles, is one of the outstanding treasures of the National Library, serving as the leading center for Kabbalah research in the world. here that scholars pour over the great works of Jewish Mysticism, such as De Lonzano's manuscript, and paving the way for continued academic research in coming generations. </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style=" margin-left: -7.1pt; line-height: 115%;"><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black; background: white;">During the 20<sup>th</sup> century the Kabbalah aroused renewed interest in the academic world. Modern research of the Kabbalah was led by </span><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: red; background: white;">Prof. Gershom Scholem </span><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black; background: white;">at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=" margin-left: -7.1pt; line-height: 115%;"><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black; background: white;">Professor Gershom Scholem </span><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">was born in Berlin in 1897 and immigrated to Palestine, then under the British Mandate, in 1923. Scholem began his career as the curator of the Judaica Department of the then Jewish National and University Library, subsequently becoming Professor of Kabbalah at the newly established Hebrew University in Jerusalem. Scholem published some 700 scholarly books and articles on all aspects of Jewish Mysticism during his lifetime.</span></p>

<p><span><span style="font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;">Although born to Jewish parents, </span></span><a title="Religion" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religion"><span style="font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;">religion</span></a><span><span style="font-family: Calibri,sans-serif;"> </span></span>did not play a central role in his education.  When i<span style="font-family: Arial;">nterviewed on this question Zweig said: "My mother and father were Jewish only through</span><span><span style="font-family: Arial;"> </span></span><a title="Accident of birth" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accident_of_birth"><span style="font-family: Arial;">accident of birth</span></a><span style="font-family: Arial;">". Zweig believed in</span><span><span style="font-family: Arial;"> universalism </span></span><a title="Internationalism (politics)" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationalism_(politics)"><span style="font-family: Arial;">internationalism</span></a><span><span style="font-family: Arial;"> </span></span><span style="font-family: Arial;">and in</span><span><span style="font-family: Arial;"> </span></span><a title="Europeanism" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Europeanism"><span style="font-family: Arial;">Europeanism</span></a><span style="font-family: Arial;"> and adopted Judaism in as far as it supported these ideas. Yet he did not renounce his Jewish faith and wrote repeatedly on Jews and Jewish themes, as in his story</span><span><span style="font-family: Arial;"> </span></span><i><a title="Buchmendel" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buchmendel"><span><span style="font-family: Arial;">Buchmendel</span></span></a></i><span style="font-family: Arial;">, and his Jewis</span>h identity clearly played a significant role in his life: “I have been vitally interested in Jewish problems all my life,” he wrote, “vitally aware of the Jewish blood that is in me ever since I have been conscious of it."</p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style=" margin-right: -2.9pt; text-align: justify; text-autospace: none;"><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black; background: white;">Following the national trauma of the </span><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">expulsion from Spain <span style=" color: black; background: white;">in 1492, Jews began to search for signs indicating the arrival of the awaited </span>Jewish Messiah<span style=" color: black; background: white;">. In the 1500s the community of </span>Safed, <span style=" color: black; background: white;">in the Galilee (the northern part of the Land of Israel), became the center of Jewish mystical, exegetical, legal and liturgical developments. </span></span></p>

<p class="DefaultStyle" style="text-align: justify;">Isaac Newton (1642-1727), the world-famous physicist<span><span style="background: white;"> </span></span><span style="background: white;">and mathematician</span>, was a central <span><span style="background: white; color: black;">figure in the scientific revolution</span></span>.</p>
<p class="DefaultStyle" style="text-align: justify;">7500 papers, written in Newton's own hand, are preserved in the collections of the National Library of Israel. These divulge an unknown side of Newton's personality. Besides being a scientist, Newton was an avid (though unusual) Christian believer, who took  a special interest in the Scriptures, believing that a deep understanding of the text will allow him to unravel the secrets of the end of days and to compute the date of  Christ's Second Coming and the Apocalypse. Of special importance is Newton's deep interest in  the Jewish sources, and his view regarding the role they of the Jews  in the process of salvation.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style=" margin-top: 0cm; margin-right: -17.05pt; margin-bottom: .0001pt; margin-left: -7.1pt; line-height: 115%; text-autospace: none;"><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; background: white;">The school of Safed started with R. Joseph Caro, R. Shlomo Alkabetz, and R. Moshe Cordovero between 1535 and 1572, and culminated with Isaac Luria, its most influential leader.  </span><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif;">While earlier Kabbalah centered on the return of man to the wellspring of his life through the contemplation of the upper worlds, </span><span style=" font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black; background: white;">the Safed mystics combined the Kabbalistic doctrine and practice with Messianic and apocalyptic trends.</span></p>

<p style=" margin: 0cm; margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 13.6pt; background: white;"><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: #010101;">When Benjamin felt the ground beginning to tremble under his feet he started thinking of the possibility of immigrating to Palestine, as did many other German-Jews at the time. Although he never reached Palestine, he had been sending material to his close friend </span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: #C00000;">Gershom Scholem</span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: #010101;">, who was at first head of The Judaica department at the National Library and since 1925 a University professor at the Hebrew University. In fact, Benjamin wrote to Scholem that these materials are all part of the <i>Beniaminia</i> archive which he was slowly building. Benjamin, like Zweig, understood that if he were to perish, the NLI is the only real safe haven for his intellectual work when all else is lost.</span></p>

<p style="TEXT-ALIGN: left; unicode-bidi: embed; DIRECTION: ltr; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt" class="MsoNormal">Franz Kafka is one of the most prominent authors writing in German during the 20<sup>th</sup> century. Born in Prague in 1883, Kafka belonged to the intellectual milieu of Jews in Prague who identified themselves with the German culture and language. Together with Max Brod, Felix Weltsch, and Oskar Baum, Kafka was part of the "Close Prague Circle", a group of Jewish authors who met regularly and collaborated in their literary work.</p>
<p style="TEXT-ALIGN: left; unicode-bidi: embed; DIRECTION: ltr; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt" class="MsoNormal">Making his living as an insurance officer, Kafka had low esteem for his work. It was only after his death that his works were published, due to the efforts of his good friend Max Brod and earned him a special place in the "Hall of Fame" of classic modern German literature.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; unicode-bidi: embed; direction: ltr;">The last census before the German occupation, held in January 1941, reported 2,150 Jewish residents in Tiachiv. They were 20% of the total population of the town.  Many of the Jews were merchants; others were craftsmen and agricultural workers and farmers.  The Jewish community was, as were most communities in Eastern Europe, a religious observant Orthodox community.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; unicode-bidi: embed; direction: ltr;"> </p>

<p style=" margin-top: 4.8pt; margin-right: 0cm; margin-bottom: 6.0pt; margin-left: 54.0pt; line-height: 14.4pt; background: white;"><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black;">The Zweigs' house in Brazil was later turned into a museum and is now known as </span><span style=" font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: Calibri,sans-serif; color: black;">Casa Stefan Zweig.</span></p>

<p>The National Library of Israel preserves several other ancient Torah scrolls, among them a scroll from Yemen, dating from around 1050-1150. The scroll contains large fragments of the Book of Numbers.</p>
<p>Another Torah scroll from Germany dates from the 15th century.</p>

<p style=" margin-top: 4.8pt; margin-right: 0cm; margin-bottom: 6.0pt; margin-left: 54.0pt; line-height: 14.4pt; background: white;"><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black;">With the rise of Hitler to power in 1933 Zweig's books were condemned in Germany and later banned. Fascism was on the rise in Austria as well, and when in 1934 the police came to search Zweig's home, he left his house never to return again. It was at this time that he divorced his first wife and moved to London, writing later that at that time he sensed the heavy clouds which were hanging above. At this point, Zweig dispersed his papers and sold his manuscript collection.</span></p>

<p style=" margin-top: 4.8pt; margin-right: 0cm; margin-bottom: 6.0pt; margin-left: 54.0pt; line-height: 14.4pt; background: white;"><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black;">In 1939 Zweig married his secretary Lotte Altmann. During these years Zweig did not express himself prominently against the Nazis or in support of the persecuted Jews, and was criticized for it by major Jewish figures like Hannah Arendt. He seems to have wanted to carry one with his life in London without much interference. Yet, it was at this time, that his writing started to center upon tormented figures, both literary and historical, who are in perilous situations. It was at this time that he wrote the biographies of Mary Queen of Scots and Marie-Antoinette, the novel <i>Beware of Pity</i>, and the novella <i>The Chess Story</i> which bears autobiographical elements.</span></p>

<p style=" margin-top: 4.8pt; margin-right: 0cm; margin-bottom: 6.0pt; margin-left: 54.0pt; line-height: 14.4pt; background: white;"><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black;">Zweig and his wife received British citizenship, but were unhappy. In the <i>World of Yesterday</i>, which Zweig wrote before his death, he describes the Jewish refugees in London, as "ghosts" looking for a country to receive them. In 1940 the Zweigs left for New-York only to discover that he was surrounded again by refugees which reminded him of the terrible events in Europe. Just a few months later the Zweigs, having taken a tour of South-America, left for Petropolis Brazil, not far from Rio de Janeiro, where they hoped to have a chance for a fresh start. Zweig even wrote a book: <i>Brazil – The Land of the Future</i>.</span></p>

<p style=" margin: 0cm; margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 13.6pt; background: white;"><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: #010101;">In 1923 Benjamin’s good friend </span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: red;">Gerschom Scholem</span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: #010101;">, influenced by </span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: red;">Martin Buber</span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: #010101;">, decided to immigrate to Palestine (Eretz Yisrael). Scholem invited Benjamin to join him, later even trying to entice him with a lectureship at the Hebrew University, but to no avail. Benjamin had never been drawn to Zionism, seeing Judaism, like </span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: red;">Zweig</span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: #010101;">, as a spiritual-cultural force in Europe:</span><span style=" font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; color: black; background: white;"> "My life experience led me to this insight: the Jews represent an elite in the ranks of the spiritually active ... For Judaism is to me in no sense an end in itself, but the most distinguished bearer and representative of the spiritual."</span></p>
